New Mills is a small mill town at the junction of the Rivers Sett and Goyt. The town is bisected by the impressive gritstone gorges of the two rivers, contained within a recreational area known as the Torrs (or the "Park under the Town"). It's unlikely to feature on many itineraries in its own right, but it's worth stopping off for an hour or two if travelling between
. Half Man Half Biscuit's laconic summary is probably fair comment: "No frills, handy for the hills, that's the way you spell New Mills."
New Mills has two railway stations:
The two stations are ¾ mile apart by road; allow at least 20 minutes to walk between the two (though a more direct route on foot is via Wirksmoor Road and a public footpath passing Torr Vale Mill).

The main bus station is at the junction of Union Street and Market Street, in the town centre close to New Mills Central station.
New Mills is just off the A6 trunk road (follow A6015 signposted

). There are pay-and-display car parks on Market Street, Torr Top Road and at the Town Hall on Bridge St (up to 30 minutes free, £0.50 for 2 hours, £1.50 for 4 hours, £2 per day), though free street parking is widely available a short distance away from the town centre in almost any direction.
The town is small enough to see on foot, but the following bus service may be useful:

content=The New Mills Festival takes place in September each year and includes a lantern procession through the Torrs as well as talks, walks, concerts, gigs and exhibitions.
directions=follow High Street down to the bridge, then keep left
content=The former town prison, now a private house with a quaint 19th-century plaque explaining its curious name.
directions=at rear of Masons Arms car park off High Street

content=Probably not worth a special visit, but worth seeking out if visiting the Drunkard's Reform, above: look on the wall at the rear of the Masons Arms car park for a rare and rather interesting early 19th-century stone-engraved advertisement for the pub, with masonic symbols and figures in 19th-century dress.

content=The Torrs is at the western end of the Sett Valley Trail, a 2½-mile trail for walkers, cyclists and horse-riders, terminating at
, a 36-ft narrowboat, for a day on the Peak Forest Canal.

content=New Mills AFC play in the Northern Premier League Division One North, the eighth tier of English football.
name=Play a round at New Mills Golf Club
content=New Mills Golf Course is an 18-hole course established in 1907 on the hillside above the town with views to Kinder Scout and the Cheshire Plain. Visiting golfers are welcome.

The main shopping streets are Market Street and Union Road in the centre of town.

value: content=Cosy café with friendly owner, mainly English food with a few Middle Eastern dishes.
content=Well-regarded traditional English takeaway—good fish and chips, generous portions.
directions=1 mile northwest of town centre; take St Marys Road (opp Station Road) then turn left along High Lea Rd/Brook Bottom Road

content=Traditional country pub in pretty, isolated stone-built hamlet at the end of a narrow no-through road. Cheapish food and Robinson's beer. Alternative routes (on foot) are via a rocky bridleway from Strines railway station (½ mile), or by walking downstream along the Goyt from the Millennium Walkway to Hague Bar picnic site (Waterside Road), climbing to the A6 in Hague Bar then following Hague Fold Road opposite (1¾ miles).
File:The Little Mill Inn, Rowarth - geograph.org.uk - 58239.jpg
directions=2½ miles northeast; exit New Mills on Mellor Road, after 1½ miles turn right into Shiloh Road—signposted Chisworth, Rowarth—then take first right (no through road) after Moorfield Arms

content=Characterful out-of-the-way place in delightful rural setting next to stream with replica waterwheel. Streamside garden (slightly spoilt by oversized decking erected for the 2006 World Cup) with adventure playground, and Pullman railway coach converted into overnight accommodation. No public transport. Free house, decent food. Live music on Friday nights. Close to pretty hamlet of Rowarth, in good walking country (the streamside path north towards Higherfold Farm is particularly attractive).
